title: Aarhus, Denmark – Visiting the City of Smiles
text:
» Slow Travel » Denmark » Aarhus, Denmark – Visiting the City of Smiles Aarhus, Denmark – Visiting the City of Smiles By monika - September 29, 2015 
Today, guest contributor, Monika, takes us to Denmark’s City of Smiles , Aarhus. 
Most people do not go beyond Copenhagen when visiting Denmark, but on a friend’s insistence, we visited Aarhus. The journey from Copenhagen to Aarhus was a comfortable, three-hour train ride before arriving in the city of smiles. Aarhus is the second largest city in Denmark and has a good mix of old world culture (read cobbled streets, museums, and idyllic surroundings) and a modern dynamism, with a reputed university and a world-class hospital. 
We were lucky to witness the Aarhus festival or, as the Danes call it, the Aarhus Festuge . The city celebrates this festival for almost ten days, every year, from late August to early September. The entire city centre was turned into a pedestrian friendly area, with cafes and restaurants brimming with people. The Aarhus River, flowing through the bustling city centre of Aarhus 
Parks like the Moelleparken were covered with tents, showcasing cultural activities from different regions of the world. We could feel the anticipation and excitement of the locals, as the festival also features music and dance performances from national and international artists. We saw artists performing Blues (the Danes are huge on this), jazz, and even some Gangnam Style inspired dance. Aarhus is also the European Culture of Capital for 2017. Tents in the park for Aarhus Festuge Musicians preform at the Aarhus Festival 
There was plenty of local cuisine on offer, ranging from smorrebrod, to open-faced seafood sandwiches, to frikadeller (meat balls); all served with a delicious dip called Remoulade , which is quite like tartar sauce with a slightly sweetish taste from the addition of sweet pickles! Shrimp salad with pickles and Remoulade Open faced sandwiches with smorrebrod – a dense and delicious Danish brown bread 
Festival apart, there are plenty of museums to visit in Aarhus. The ARoS Museum practically looms over the city, with its Rainbow panorama. The ARoS Museum houses ever-changing collections from Danish and other international artists. We enjoyed the collections modelled on the traditional art history, but what caught my eye was a floor called ‘Out of the Darkness’. The exhibits all make use of darkness and light in a very interesting way and are open to personal interpretation; definitely a must see if you are visiting the museum. The star attraction of the ARoS Museum is definitely the Rainbow panorama on its top, designed by the Icelandic-Danish artist, Oliafur Elliasson. The panorama is a glass passageway designed in colours of the rainbow and offers a wonderful view of the city. The ARoS Museum is crowned with the Rainbow Panorama 

Another interesting visit in Aarhus is the Den Gamle By , an open-air museum showcasing Danish life in the past. What gives this museum its distinctive appeal, is its Old World charm, wherein you can experience the neighbourhood in Hans Christian Andersen’s days. Sadly, we couldn’t do this museum, since we were just visiting for the weekend. (Sounds like a good excuse to plan a trip to Aarhus again.) 
Aarhus also boasts the largest music school in the country, wherein children and adults can learn singing and also playing instruments. The Latin Quarter, well known for its cafes and a spirited atmosphere, is also worth a visit. The Aarhus music school 
While in Aarhus, don’t forget to visit the original Legoland, in Billund . Billund has the second busiest airport in Denmark and is a little more than 100 kilometres from Aarhus. The Legoland Park, in Billund, has something for everyone: an aquarium, rides, and water splashes. There are miniature replicas of many Danish and international attractions, all made from Lego. There are 3D film shows and games teaching kids about traffic lights and rules. There is plenty to keep children and their parents amused. Don’t miss the original Legolandin Billund, Denmark 
While in Denmark, don’t forget to buy a souvenir from Illums Bolighus , an excellent representation of the sleekness and austere nature of the Danish design. 
We found the Aarhus locals happy and eager to help, though, I have to add, the sun was shining over the weekend and the entire city was gripped in a festival-like mood. The city is a fifteen minute bicycle ride to the harbour, forest and the beach, therefore scoring high points on the liveability index. A breathtaking view of one of Aarhus’s many lakes 
And if all this doesn’t make you happy, there were free hugs as well! With Love from Aarhus, Denmark
